root: ^Oh! Private Investigator, how are things going?
^Depends. Do you think you should be?
^Ms. Sweets, how long have you been selling mercury?
^Yes, Ms. Sweets. I know you've got a stash in your locker.
^But you promised not to look inside my locker!
^Whose is it then? Ms. Chef Frances?
^No! She would never. She always told me...
^Well, if it wasn't you, it must've been her.
^Who else has access to your locker code?
^Frannie's Diner is so well loved in this area, and for the chef to have been caught selling mercury!
^The place will have to shut down.
^Stop! Fine, it was me! I was selling the mercury.
^How do I know you're not covering for Ms. Chef Frances?
^I can give you all the details she wouldn't know.
^I sold mercury to Mr. Bowler: three vials every Fridays.
^After he finished his drink, he'd head to the alley through the hallway, and we'd make the swap.
^Mercury for money, Mr. Trilby. Do keep up.
^The diner business on this side of town doesn't pay much.
^He was also the Minister of Health, you know, so he'd let us pass health inspections.
^So...It's Monday, not Friday. Why was he here?
^Oh, he was here nearly every day. He liked the sticky smoothies.
^Did he approach you, asking for more mercury?
^Perhaps he threatened to expose you, and you dealt with him?
^Oh my Fabric! You think I killed him?
^You're quite a likely suspect, Ms. Sweets.
^Selling mercury doesn't make me a killer, Mr. Trilby.
^I understand that quite well, but you did have the motive and the opportunity for it.
^I don't know what to tell you, Mr. Trilby. I didn't kill him.
^Where were you at the time of the murder?
^I was doing my job. I believe any of the customers can confirm that.
^Thank you for your time, Ms. Sweets. I'm sure I'll talk to you again soon.
